Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of finely pecked engraved rock art on rock surface, showing two giraffes, three ostriches, one antelope, one unidentified quadruped and several unidentified shapes. All animals upright. Top (left to right): Outline of schematic ostrich; upright and facing right. Neck intersected by infilled curved giraffe neck facing left. Sscimitar-horned oryx superimposed by unidentified infilled quadruped (bull?) facing same way; ostrich, infilled with disc lacking infill on body, facing left. Bottom (left to right): Giraffe facing left with head cut off edge of image; infilled ostrich facing right, superimposing legs of other giraffe mentioned above; unidentified shape (legs)? Giraffe and antelope engravings have a darker patina than others. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.325. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
